title: Tricked into signing trust amend & removed as a trustee. Trust papers withheld, missed hearing & unaware of chg. Any recourse?
question: I was mislead when asked to sign a document for my moms trust. I just recently discovered that I was removed as a successor trustee. My mom then had the trust papers with hearing date sent to her home instead of mine and she withheld the papers so I was unaware of change and missed hearing. I found papers in her papers few days ago. She is still alive. But she did this 3 yrs ago. The paper I signed was a consent to modification of trust. I was told this was to modify trust for tax reasons. I never received notice of hearing or the trust. What happened was I was removed as successor trustee and trust amended with some special distribution clauses that I in no way would agree to. (release health records to a family member I do not trust or they may withhold money). I was lied to and deceived intentionally to give my brother full control of me and my daughter. This is not acceptable to me and not what my father wanted when original trust was set up. He is deceased. I am not sure how to proceed. But again, giving control to my brother is not acceptable, we have no relationship and he has proven untrustworthy.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Power of attorney,Probate court,Trusts,Trustee,Successor trustee,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
Your attorney may petition court to set aside amendments based on fraud and lack of notice.
You will need attorney assistance to prepare matter for settlement or litigation.

Don't delay getting a trusts attorney to represent you. Find/consult/hire a lawyer in your area using the Avvo feature "Find a Lawyer". Make a list of 4-5 having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back from one, go on to the next on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person.

Hello,

Without seeing the documentation it is difficult to provide an opinion. So I am going to work under the assumption that this is your mom's trust and the assets in it belong to her and some of the assets was what was left to her from your Dad's estate.

If that is the case, because the assets belong to her and she is still alive, she can make whatever changes she wants as to who is to be her successor trustee and distribution of assets.

The question is whether your mother had full control over the trust. If she did have full control, you are out of luck. If, however, as seems more likely, her control was limited and the trust that your father established was not subject to her power of appointment, you may have a case.
You need to have an experienced trust attorney look into this.
The problem is that if your mother could remove you as beneficiary, then she could impose practically any conditions she wanted. You need to have the actual trust reviewed, as well as the court case.
